Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Thermodynamics of Nucleation: From Water to Atmospheric Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor George Shields of Bucknell University to determine structures and energies of molecular complexes relevant to atmospheric aerosols. These complexes are formed from water molecules, sulfuric acid molecules, and other trace molecules found in the atmosphere. These complexes are important because they are relate to the fundamental basis of how clouds form, and the mechanism for cloud formation is currently not known. The project is also having a broad impact through its model of a sustained and productive undergraduate research experience involving the same students, including minorities and women, throughout their undergraduate years.

Professor George Shields and co-workers are purusing a joint computational/experimental study toward establishing the minimum energy structures and the thermodynamics for formation of hydrogen-bonded complexes. These studies allow for the assessment of the ability of state-of-the-art computational chemistry methods to model water clusters that can be directly compared, and help guide state-of-the-art microwave spectroscopy experiments. The Shields group is determining the structures and thermodynamics of molecular clusters containing sulfuric acid, bases, and water, that are believed to serve as neutral and ionic cloud condensation nuclei. These methods are expected to allow for the prediction of the relative abundance of all potentially relevant complexes, providing insight on which ones are of atmospheric importance in the cloud nucleation process. In a much broader sense, the techniques being developed here may provide atmospheric scientists with new ways to relate air quality/composition to cloud nucleation/pattern development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to apply computational chemistry methods to model the formation of atmospheric aerosols and water clusters at a molecular level. These complexes are formed from water molecules, sulfuric acid molecules, and other trace molecules found in the atmosphere. These complexes are important because they are the fundamental basis for how clouds form, and the mechanism for the how clouds begin to form is currently not known. Understanding how aerosols form has the potential to benefit society since aerosols can possibly slow down the rate of global warming. Sulfates have the largest cooling effect among aerosols and the presence of sulfuric acid has been shown to strongly correlate with aerosol formation. We have advanced the knowledge of how small molecules such as sulfuric acid, bases, and water form small clusters in the atmosphere. Our results show that there is a synergistic effect between sulfuric acid, bases, and water. Specifically, the presence of two different types of bases has a stronger nucleating effect than the same bases alone. In addition we have used water clusters as an excellent model system to compare experiment to theory. Small water clusters determined experimentally validate our theoretical methods, and our methods guide the search for larger water clusters studied by experiment. We have published eight papers in the scientific literature, two book chapters, and a book during this grant period.

During this project we have worked with 12 undergraduates, one research scientist, and a postdoctoral associate. Six of the undergraduates are female, and three are African-American males, so that 75% of the students working on this project were diverse. In addition, the research scientist is African-American, and the postdoctoral associate is Asian-American. Both the education of undergraduates to understand the scientific method through significant research experiences, and the education of underrepresented students in chemistry are of great benefit to society and advance and improve societal outcomes. Three of the 12 undergraduates have graduated to date. They are an African-American male who is now in graduate school in computer science at Vanderbilt University, an Asian-American female who is now in graduate school in chemistry at Cornell University, and a male who is now in law school at Elon University.
